explanation:
The correct calculation uses tangent: \( \tan(32^\circ) = \frac{\text{opposite}}{\text{adjacent}} = \frac{p}{6} \).  
The student incorrectly applied sine: \( \sin(32^\circ) = \frac{p}{6} \), which assumes the hypotenuse is 6 cm.  

The error stems from misapplying the sine ratio (opposite/hypotenuse) instead of tangent (opposite/adjacent). The student recognized \( p \) as the opposite side but mistakenly treated the given adjacent side (6 cm) as the hypotenuse. This directly reflects a failure to properly associate the given sides with the correct trigonometric ratio via SOHCAHTOA.  

This is distinct from confusing adjacent/opposite labels (which would involve swapping sides) or mixing sine/cosine (which would retain hypotenuse usage). The error specifically substitutes hypotenuse for adjacent in the ratio, indicating a flawed application of the trigonometric relationships rather than a side-labeling issue.
